text:

Now he’s on to the final again. It will get harder. But he already knows that. But he already knows that. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/2lBu3Pb Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address.   Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs James: Chase Elliott makes another Daytona statement Brant James, USA TODAY Sports 9:22 p.m. ET Feb. 23, 2017 CLOSE x Share USA TODAY Sports' Brant James sits down with FOX Sports' pit reporter Matt Yocum to discuss the new NASCAR point system. Daytona 500 airs Saturday at 1 p.m. ET on Fox. USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott celebrates with his team after winning the first Can-Am Duel at Daytona Thursday night. (Photo: Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Chase Elliott passed another Daytona test on Thursday night. Now he’s on to the final again. It will get harder. But he already knows that. 
Make no mistake, had the 150-mile qualifying race Elliott won at Daytona International Speedway been the actual Daytona 500, Kevin Harvick and Jamie McMurray, former winners of NASCAR’s greatest race, would not have been so civil. Brad Keselowski, who has never won the Daytona 500, would have acted out like he did on the final lap of the non-points Clash exhibition, sending leader Denny Hamlin careening after a poorly timed block attempt. But none of them wanted to wreck fast race cars, just as much as Elliott didn’t want to lose the car that won the pole and will lead the field to green . 
There had been no doubt that Elliott, 21, had been provided fast cars by Hendrick Motorsports in his first two attempts at the Daytona 500. He won the pole both times. But after finishing sixth in his qualifying race and leading just two laps last season, the prodigy wrecked his speedy No. 24 Chevrolet sufficiently to relegate himself to a 37th-place finish in last year's race. 
MORE NASCAR: Danica Patrick on NASCAR future: 'I don't need an exit strategy' 
Another year, another pole, and another chance to prove himself in the prestige season opener of the Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series season. Winning on Thursday is no assurance of success on Sunday in the race that matters most. But in recovering from an early attack by the mob to regain the lead from Keselowski on Lap 35 of 60, then defending it with vigorous blocking, Elliott suggested the flair and the calculation required to succeed in the odd exercise that is restrictor-plate racing. 
Daytona’s demands on finding the proper balance for a car remain patently evident for Elliott, as he and teammate Dale Earnhardt Jr. slid off Turn 4 in the Daytona 500 last season. He mastered it Thursday, but even racing conditions will be different Sunday with a day start and a warmer, slicker track. 
PHOTOS: Behind the wheel with Chase Elliott Facebook   Chase Elliott, the son of NASCAR Hall of Famer Bill Elliott, was born Nov. 28, 1995. The younger Elliott won the 2014 Xfinity Series championship and became a full-time Sprint Cup driver in 2016, taking over the No. 24 car for the retired Jeff Gordon. Mike DiNovo, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott (24) crosses the finish line at Michigan International Speedway just behind Joey Logano on June 12, 2016. Logano beat Elliott .889 seconds to prevent the rookie from scoring his first career Sprint Cup Series win. Mike DiNovo, USA TODAY Sports Rookie Chase Elliott became the youngest driver to win the Daytona 500 pole on Feb. 14, 2016. Elliott was 20 years, 2 months and 17 days old on the day of pole qualifying. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott poses with his No. 24 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet after winning the Daytona 500 pole on Feb. 14, 2016. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Xfinity Series driver Chase Elliott (9) celebrates in Victory Lane after winning the Virginia College Savings 250 at Richmond International Raceway on Sept. 11, 2015. Amber Searls, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott celebrates with fans after winning the NASCAR Nationwide Championship after finishing fifth in the Nationwide Series auto race at Phoenix International Raceway Saturday, Nov. 8, 2014, in Avondale, Ariz. Ross D. Franklin, AP NASCAR driver Chase Elliott is congratulated by Dale Earnhardt Jr. at the end of the DAV 200 Honoring America's Veterans at Phoenix International Raceway in Avondale on Saturday, November 8, 2014. David Wallace, The Republic Chase Elliott celebrates with his father, Hall of Fame driver Bill and mother Cindy after winning the NASCAR Nationwide Series Championship. Todd Warshaw, Getty Images Chase Elliott celebrates with a burnout after winning the NASCAR Nationwide Series Championship. Jerry Markland, Getty Images Nationwide Series driver Chase Elliott celebrates after winning the O'Reilly Auto Parts 300 at Texas Motor Speedway. Jerome Miron, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott (center) with crew chief Greg Ives (left) and team owner Rick Hendrick before the Blue Jeans Go GreenTM 200 at Phoenix International Raceway. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott (9) and Elliott's team owner Dale Earnhardt Jr. (88) race each other during the O'Reilly Auto Parts 300 at Texas Motor Speedway. Jerome Miron, USA TODAY Sports Chase walks with dad and 1988 Cup champion Bill Elliott on pit road before the NASCAR Nationwide Series Dover 200 at Dover International Speedway. Nick Laham, Getty Images Confetti descends on Chase Elliott during the victory lane celebration after the EnjoyIllinios.com 300 at Chicagoland Speedway, his third win of 2014. Jeff Zelevansky, Getty Images Chase Elliott competes in the No. 9 car during the Kansas Lottery 300 at Kansas Speedway. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott with his parents Cindy and Bill after winning the O'Reilly Auto Parts 300 at Texas Motor Speedway in April 2014. It was his first win on the national touring series. Chris Graythen, Getty Images Chase Elliott celebrates winning the VFW Sports Clips Help a Hero 200 at Darlington Raceway, just one week after his breakthrough win at Texas Motor Speedway. Peter Casey, USA TODAY Sports Nationwide Series driver Chase Elliott celebrates winning the VFW Sports Clips Help a Hero 200 at Darlington Raceway. Peter Casey, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott is shown before the Drive To Stop Diabetes 300 at Bristol Motor Speedway. Andrew Weber, USA TODAY Sports Nationwide Series driver Chase Elliott competes during the Jimmy Johns Freaky Fast 300 at Chicagoland Speedway. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Chase Elliott celebrates with his mother Cindy and father Bill after winning the Pocono ARCA 200 at Pocono Raceway. Matthew O'Haren, USA TODAY Sports ARCA Racing Series driver Chase Elliott prior to the Pocono ARCA 200 at Pocono Raceway. Matthew O'Haren, USA TODAY Sports A young Chase Elliott with father Bill after the elder Elliott won the pole at Charlotte Motor Speedway. Chuck Burton, Associated Press Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
Elliott admitted, as is the case with most honest Daytona 500 pole-winners, that their accomplishment was virtually all a product of the motor and the race car crafted and honed by their team back in North Carolina. Elliott, therefore, had questions to answer after plowing through the grass on Lap 18 and finishing 37th with his damaged car last year. 
On Thursday, Elliott held the lead twice for 25 laps. Early on, he was consumed by a pack filled with drivers with allegiances to other manufacturers, notably the entire four-car Joe Gibbs Racing contingent of Toyotas. 
Runner-up McMurray said Elliott did “a really good job,” in his estimation. “Awesome,” in fact. And even with the win, much of the field considers Team Penske’s Keselowski and former 500 winner Joey Logano the favorites. 
But Elliott made his case. Now he has to go make it again. 
Follow James on Twitter @brantjames 
PHOTOS: History of the Daytona 500 Facebook   The Daytona 500, the premier race in NASCAR, has been held annually since 1959. The 59th running of the Great American Race is Feb. 26, 2017. Lynne Sladky, AP Pre-Daytona 500: Bill France Sr., center, and others gather at the Streamline Hotel in Daytona Beach, Fla., in 1947 for meetings that resulted in the formation of NASCAR. Daytona Racing Archives Pre-Daytona 500: An aerial view of the North Turn and grandstand as cars race on the Daytona Beach Road Course in 1950. Daytona Racing Archives Pre-Daytona 500: One year before the first Daytona 500, Glen Wood (22) leads Banjo Matthews (M-4) in a 1958 Modified Sportsman race in Daytona Beach, Fla. Daytona Racing Archives Lee Petty (42), driving an Oldsmobile, and Johnny Beauchamp (73), driving a Thunderbird, were neck and neck on the last lap of the inaugural Daytona 500 in 1959, but Petty nosed out Beauchamp at the finish line. AP Junior Johnson leads Fireball Roberts and Richard Petty during the 1962 Daytona 500. Roberts won the 1962 race two years after Johnson won his lone title in 1960. Daytona Racing Archives Richard Petty poses with the championship trophy after earning the first of seven Daytona 500 wins in 1964. Jim Kerlin, AP Fred Lorenzen (28) outdueled Junior Johnson (27) to win the 1965 Daytona 500. Daytona Racing Archives Fullscreen Former Miss USA Diana Batts, of Washington, D.C., gives a big kiss to Mario Andretti after he won the 1967 Daytona 500. Andretti remains the only driver ever to win the Indianapolis 500 (1969), Daytona 500 (1967) and the Formula One World Championship (1978). AP Richard Petty holds the record for most Daytona 500 wins with seven. Here he drives to victory during the 1971 race. Daytona Racing Archives Fullscreen A.J. Foyt gets a big kiss from Union 76 Racestopper Cheryl Johnson after winning the 1972 Daytona 500. Foyt is the only driver to win the Indianapolis 500 (which he won four times), the Daytona 500, the 24 Hours of Daytona, and the 24 Hours of Le Mans. AP Former taxi cab driver Benny Parsons raises the championship trophy after winning the 1975 Daytona 500. AP David Pearson was able to coax his wrecked car across the finish line to win the 1976 Daytona 500. Daytona Racing Archives In one of the most famous crashes in NASCAR history, David Pearson and Richard Petty wreck while racing for the lead on the final lap of the 1976 Daytona 500. Daytona Racing Archives Fullscreen Cale Yarborough, right, kicks and pushes Bobby Allison, center, who is catching his leg as Donnie Allison, left, tries to pull his brother free from the fight which started after Yarborough collided with Donnie on the last lap of the 1979 Daytona 500. Ric Feld, AP Richard Petty, (middle, with STP cap and sunglasses), poses with his family after winning his sixth Daytona 500 title in 1979. Petty won for the seventh and final time in 1981. Daytona Racing Archives Cale Yarborough takes the checkered flag at the Daytona 500 for the final time in 1984. Yarborough also won in 1983, '77, and '68. Pete Bauer, AP Bill Elliott won the second of his two Daytona 500 titles in 1987. He won his first Great American Race two years earlier in 1985. Kathy Willens, AP Fullscreen Bobby Allison, right, celebrates his victory in the 1988 Daytona 500 by pouring a Miller beer over the head of his son Davey Allison, who he beat in an emotional finish. Davey Allison won the 1992 race, while Bobby Allison also won in 1982 and 1978. Dozier Mobley, Getty Images Darrell Waltrip celebrates his lone Daytona 500 title by performing the "Ickey Shuffle," a dance created by NFL player Ickey Woods, after winning the 1989 Great American Race. RacingOne ISC Archives via Getty Images Dale Jarrett lets out a yell as he climbs out of his car after winning the 35th annual Daytona 500 in 1993. Jarrett would add two more Daytona 500 titles, in 1996 and 2000. Terry Renna, AP Jeff Gordon (24), Terry Labonte (5) and Ricky Craven (25) led Hendrick Motorsports to a 1-2-3 finish at the 1997 Daytona 500. Gordon would win the Daytona 500 twice more: in 1999 and 2005. Phil Coale, AP Crew members line up along pit road to congratulate Dale Earnhardt as the NASCAR legend finally wins his first Daytona 500 in 1998, 20 years after his first Daytona 500 start in 1979. Roger Simms, Daytona Beach News-Journal via AP Dale Earnhardt (3) hits the wall after getting hit by Ken Schrader (36) during the 2001 Daytona 500. Earnhardt died as a result of the crash that stands as one of the most horrific moments in NASCAR history. Bob Sweeten, AP Fullscreen Shortly after winning the 2001 Daytona 500, Michael Waltrip talks about the death of friend and competitor Dale Earnhardt, who died after crashing on the last lap. Waltrip would have a chance to better celebrate after winning the 2003 Daytona 500. Terry Renna, AP Fullscreen Two-time Daytona 500 champion Sterling Marlin gets a reprimand from a track official after he tried to pull a bent piece of sheet metal away from his tire during a red-flag stop in the 2002 race. Marlin's gaffe will forever be part of NASCAR's lore, with some saying his illegal attempt to fix his car under the red flag cost him a victory. Dow Graham, AP Ward Burton, center, is showered with confetti in victory lane after winning the 2002 Daytona 500 after Sterling Marlin's penalty. Matthew Ratajczak, The Stuart News via AP Crew members converge on Dale Earnhardt Jr., left, at the start-finish line after he won the 2004 Daytona 500, three years after his father died as a result of a last-lap crash in the 2001 event. Jonathan Ferrey, Getty Images Ryan Newman won his only race of 2008 at the Daytona 500, bringing Penske Racing its first win at The Great American Race. Jamie Squire, Getty Images Workers repair damage to the track as a result of a pothole in Turn 2 on lap 122 during the 2010 Daytona 500. The race was red-flagged for almost two hours before Jamie McMurray eventually won. Jerry Markland, Getty Images for NASCAR Trevor Bayne, at 20-years, one-day old, became the youngest winner of the Daytona 500, in 2011. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Safety crews work to put out a fire from a jet-fueled track dryer that was hit by Juan Pablo Montoya's car (not pictured) under caution during the 2012 Daytona 500. Andrew Weber, USA TODAY Sports Safety workers clean up the track with Tide laundry detergent after a jet-fueled track dryer burst into flames when it was struck by Juan Pablo Montoya's car under caution during the 2012 Daytona 500. John Harrelson, Getty Images for NASCAR Matt Kenseth earned the second of two Daytona 500 wins in 2012. He won his first in 2009. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Jimmie Johnson crosses the finish line to win the 2013 Daytona 500. Kevin Liles, USA TODAY Sports Dale Earnhardt Jr took the 2014 Daytona 500 on the 10th anniversary of his first win there. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Joey Logano won the 2015 race, his first Daytona 500 victory. Andrew Weber, USA TODAY Sports In the closest finish in history, Denny Hamlin (11) beats Martin Truex Jr. (78) to win the 2016 Daytona 500 by .011 second. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay
